question: Question_01_(b)
statement:
Consider the system of equations in the variables
\emph{x}\textsubscript{1}, \emph{x}\textsubscript{2},
\emph{x}\textsubscript{3}:

\begin{align*}
&x_1 + 2x_2 + 3x_3 &= 1\\
&x_1 + x_2 + 2x_3 &= 2\\
&2x_1 + 3x_2 + (5+t)x_3 &= 2\end{align*} For those \emph{t} for which the system is consistent,
give the solution set in parametric form.
sols:
In the first part of the question, we calculated the row reduced form of
the augmented matrix of the system and obtained:

\begin{align*}\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
1 & 2 & 3 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & 1 & -1 \\
0 & 0 & t & -1
\end{array} \right]\end{align*} For which we saw that unless \emph{t} = 0, there
is always a unique solution (since the matrix has full rank in that
case).

The third row of the matrix translates into

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
tx_3 = -1\end{align*} Which is equivalent to

\begin{align*}x_3 = -\frac{1}{t}\end{align*} (recall that we suppose here that \emph{t} is NOT
equal to 0.)

The second row gives

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x_2 +x_3 = -1\end{align*} and so

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x_2 -\frac{1}{t} = -1\end{align*} which gives

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x_2 = -1 +\frac{1}{t} = \frac{1-t}{t}\end{align*}

And finally, the first row gives

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x_1 + 2x_2 + 3x_3 = 1\end{align*} Substituting for \emph{x}\textsubscript{2} and
\emph{x}\textsubscript{3} we obtain

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x_1 + \frac{2(1-t)}{t} - \frac{3}{t} = 1\end{align*} And hence

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x_1 = \frac{t-2(1-t)+3}{t} = \frac{3t+1}{t}\end{align*}

And we obtain that the system has a unique solution (when \emph{t} is
not zero) which depends on \emph{t} and the solution is

\begin{align*}\left[ \begin{array}{c}
x_1 \\
\\
x_2 \\
\\
x_3
\end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c}
\frac{3t+1}{t} \\
\\
\frac{1-t}{t} \\
\\
-\frac{1}{t}
\end{array} \right]\end{align*}
hints:
You can determine the solution of a system from its row-reduced form.
Parametric just means you keep carrying the variable \emph{t}, so your
solution is a general formula that gives the solution of the system in
terms of \emph{t}.
